The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

On December 10, 2013 the Board approved a Contract to Galeb Paving, Inc. in the amount of $756,000 for parking lots & street maintenances of the Evergreen Valley College Campus.  The scope of work included the first phase of a northern loop road to connect the east and west EVC parking lots and provide pavement marking for curbs of parking lots 1, 1A, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8 and select portions of Paseo de Arboles Road. 
	 
In accordance with the contract terms, Change Order #001 provides a twenty-three (23) calendar day no-cost time extension to the contract substantial completion date from May 10, 2014 to June 2, 2014.  The overall construction duration was delayed due to unforeseen weather impact to the site conditions and critical path work activities.
	 
There is no cost adjustment necessary to the Galeb Paving, Inc. contract as a result of this change.  The original contract amount of $756,000 remains unchanged.
	 
Original Completion Date:                   May 10, 2014
Completion Date with this change:     June 2, 2014

Allana Buick and Bers (ABB) is the design firm engaged by the District to address the water infiltration and leakage issues at the Gullo Student Center on the Evergreen Valley College campus.  Since the original PAA was approved in May 2012 to address the roof, the District has taken a measured approach to authorizing additional work.  Revisions have been issued previously to expand the ABB assessment to include the exterior wall conditions, to add Division of the State Architect (DSA)-mandated design tasks and for focused initial construction administration tasks.  
	 
	 
This Revision No. 004 incorporates services to support changes that have occurred due to the complexity of the project: provide construction administration services through the revised project substantial completion date, provide design services and coordination with DSA for roof-mounted structural tie-offs adjacent to rooftop mechanical units, revised window anchorage points, and revised metal panel structural hat channels.

On April 10, 2012 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Lionakis for design services for the Automotive Technology Project at Evergreen Valley College. 
	 
The original intent for the Automotive Technology project was to use the design-bid-build delivery method and the design contract with Lionakis was negotiated in that way.  Late in design it was found to be advantageous to convert the project to the Lease-Leaseback approach.  Revision No. 003 adds construction cost reconciliation services to the design contract including reconciliation meetings with the contractor, review and independent estimation of all direct and indirect costs for all trade disciplines, analysis of unit rates, quantities, overhead and profit, and any contingencies.
	 
Lionakis submitted written pricing proposals for changes noted above.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The one item in this Revision results in an ADD to the contract of $2,530.

items.item_details:
It is required by the Division of the State Architect (DSA) to have DSA-approved inspector to ensure compliance with DSA requirements on the project. Since this is a large and complex project, Gilbane and the District chose to issue a public RFQ for Inspector of Record Services.  The RFQ was advertised in the Daily Journal on February 21, 2014 and February 28, 2014, and posted on the District’s Purchasing Bids website.  
	 
On March 17, 2014 the District received eleven proposals in response to a public RFP for Inspector of Record services for the Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project. The proposals were evaluated by a committee including representatives of District Purchasing, the design team, the General Contractor, and Evergreen Valley College.  Proposals were scored with points in categories including: form of RFQ response, availability of personnel, position rates & proposed fees, experience of lead IOR, and references of lead IOR.  The four contractors with the highest overall scores were selected to continue to the next step. 
	 
On April 11, 2014 the four selected contractors were interviewed by the selection committee.  Gilbane facilitated the interviews, however it was found that one of the interviewees was a past Gilbane employee, thus Gilbane left the room and did not participate in the decision process.  The interview committee assigned points to each interviewee which were combined with the points from the proposal evaluation scoring.   Eagle Enterprises had the highest combined score and is recommended as IOR for the South Campus Building project.  The Exhibit A Scope of Work and Exhibit B contract amount of $450,000 are based on the RFQ and the negotiated hourly rates.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of an Independent Contractor Agreement to Eagle Enterprises in the amount of $450,000 for the Inspector of Record services of the South Campus Development Project at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On March 4, 2014, the Board Legislative Committee, composed of Trustees Wendy Ho, Jeff Lease and Mayra Cruz, and staffed by Executive Director Rosalie Ledesma, convened its first of three meetings to undertake a comprehensive Legislative Plan and to formalize a set of principles to guide the legislative work of the Board.  
	 
Tonight’s presentation provides an overview of the Board Legislative Committee’s work to date.  It covers the charge and composition of the committee, “branding” of Board legislative advocacy, alignment of legislative work with the Board of Trustees and SJECCD's efforts as well as recent legislative advocacy.  The final portion of the presentation includes recommended action for approval of “Tier One” and “Tier Two” legislative bills that will support student success.
	 
Tier One bills are those bills with great and more immediate impact to student success because they will reduce costs or remove financial barriers for SJECCD students to pursue their education in a more timely manner.  Tier One bills are those bills wherein staff will provide testimony, hold meetings with legislators and staffers, write and submit bill amendments, craft resolutions—if warranted—and write and submit letters to legislators and others with influence on each bill.    
	 
Tier Two bills are those pieces of legislation where staff will take a less active role, but will nonetheless regularly monitor each bill and write letters of support.   These bills were selected because they will (if passed) also support student success and, for the most part, aligned with SJECCD’s Strategic Plan for 2013-2017.  We included Strategic Plan goals because of our Committee’s emphasis on alignment with major work being conducted by the District. Alignment of the work efforts we undertake are critical for resource efficiency in order to maximize opportunities for supporting student success.   
	 
Based on the work of the Board Legislative Committee, which included a review and analysis of legislative bills as well as related communication and meetings with legislators, staffers, students, and district bill-content experts, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended bills for the 2014 legislative session with priority given to Tier One (Attachment A_1) bills and secondary consideration to Tier Two (Attachment A_2) bills.  
	 
The third attached document (Attachment B_2014 Bills info only) are those remaining bills for consideration in the 2014 legislative session that are provided for informational purposes only because they impact our Community College system or because they address a population of K-12 students who will likely matriculate to SJECCD.

items.item_details:
To comply with Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) Statements 43 and 45, the San Jose Evergreen Community College District developed and implemented a Substantive Plan focused on the delivery and funding of health and welfare benefits for eligible retirees and their spouses.
	 
Taxable Other Post Employment Benefits (OPEB) bonds were issued on May 14, 2009, in the amount of $46,775,000 to fund this liability and funds were deposited into the OPEB Trust.  Issuing the bonds ensured that the District complied with GASB Statements 43 and 45, allowed the District to determine how the benefit costs and long-term liability would be funded over time, and provided the District with savings to the General Fund.  the District incorporated capitalized interest to provide two years without any OPEB-related debt service payments from the General Fund.  
	 
On March 13, 2012, the Board of Trustees adopted Resolution 031312-2 authorizing the re-marketing of the bonds to further reduce the exposure to the General Fund and to lock in a fixed rate for 15 years.  It is projected that in FY 2013-2014 the General Fund will contribute $1,953,150 toward the $2,477,542 debt-service obligation, which remains less than the cost of benefits of approximately $3,270,701.
	 
An updated actuarial study by Nyhart-Epler dated June 30, 2013, determined that the long-term liability associated with these benefit commitments was $40,148,891 with net assets of $47,450,296, which means that the liability was over-funded as of June 30, 2013, by $7,301,405 or a funded ratio of 118%.
	 
The Retirement Board of Authority (RBOA) oversees and implements the OPEB Trust, which has a targeted net investment rate of return of 7.88%.  Attached for reference is the actuarial report dated June 30, 2013; the performance letter dated April 18, 2014, from Benefit Trust; and the presentation from the RBOA.

items.item_details:
On October 7, 2005, the Governor signed Assembly Bill No. 1234, which requires that if a local agency provides any type of compensation, salary, or stipend to, or reimburses the expenses of a member of its 'legislative body' (as that term is defined in California Government Code Section 54952), that local agency's officials must receive training in ethics.  Cal. Government Code § 53235 defines the requirements of AB 1234, and Section § 53235.1(b) mandates that ethics training be received at least once every two years. 
	 
In order to ensure the Board of Trustees is compliant with AB 1234 and California Government Code § 53235, the Board will receive ethics training provided by Santa Clara County Assistant County Counsel members Danny Chou and Steve Mitra.

items.item_details:
This information item will provide a status update on the Measure G-2004 & Measure G-2010 bond programs and highlight several of the active projects as well as provide a review of Gilbane's performance through year three (FY2013/14) and information relating to the renewal of Gilbane's agreement for year four (FY2014/15). 
	 
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010.  Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize a program and construction management firm to provide program and construction management services to the colleges and District to support implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects. In keeping with the District's desire to promote accountability, efficiency and cost effectiveness, the District went through a formal Request for Qualifications process to seek the services of a Program and Construction Management firm to provide system-wide coordination and oversight of all capital improvement work performed under the Measure G-2010 bond program.  Gilbane Building Company was selected through this process.
	 
Since the initial one-year contract with Gilbane awarded by the Board on May 10, 2011, policies and procedures for operating under the Bond have been implemented, overall program and detailed project scheduling has been established and maintained, accounting and purchasing procedures have been put in place and numerous projects have commenced design and are going into construction on the campuses and for the District. Each contract was for time and materials only at a not-to-exceed amount, with the third year (FY2013/14) value of $5,627,569.  The agreement has the option to renew annually through 2018.  The proposed contract amount for the fourth year (FY2014/15) is valued at $5,724,420.
	 
As for the Measure G-2004 bond program, the FY2013/14 contract is $736,416 and the proposed FY2014/15 contract is $980,785.
	 
The Board is being asked to review this information on May 13, 2014 and then take action on a year four (FY2014/15) contract renewal for the Measure G-2010 bond program and a contract for FY2014/15 for the Measure G-2004 bond program at the June 10, 2014 Board of Trustees meeting.
